statement:
Suppose a constant $x$ is transcendental over some field $F$. Then
$\sqrt[n]{x}$ is also transcendental over $F$ for any $n\geq 1$.

Let $\overline{F}$ denote an algebraic closure of $F$. Assume for the
sake of contradiction that $\sqrt[n]{x}\in\overline{F}$. Then since
algebraic numbers are closed under multiplication (and thus
exponentiation by positive integers), we have
$(\sqrt[n]{x})^n=x\in \overline{F}$, so that $x$ is algebraic over $F$,
creating a contradiction.
